messageBody:
re - assert countingFrom: Keith Ray
>As I said before, I would just want a warning when a test method is empty
or has no asserts...
> but I don't want to go to the trouble of getting some code-coverage tool
working.

Interesting. But in my case I would have a lot of "false warnings" because I
have a lot of methods that validate something and throw if it's invalid (but
do nothing if valid, so return is void). The tests look like that :

public void testAValidationTest() throws Exception {
validator.validate(VALID_DATA);
}

So, no asserts, but a perfectly valid test case.

I would then probably get 200 warnings, so how could I differentiate the
legitimate ones from false ones?

If this feature goes in, it should be possible to turn it on/off, like
assert counting I guess :)

mathieu

----- Original Message -----
From: Keith Ray
To: 'junit@yahoogroups.com'
Sent: Friday, July 27, 2001 12:36 PM
Subject: [junit] re - assert counting


As I said before, I would just want a warning when a test method is empty or
has no asserts... but I don't want to go to the trouble of getting some
code-coverage tool working.
> I think Jeff has hit the nail on the head, I too would like to be
> able to get some feedback when the number of asserts has changed
> for the same reasons.
>
> Seems to me that the simplest thing that could possibly work is
> to count the asserts.
I'm not using the current JUnit, since my old version is doing just fine,
with no class-loader problems because it doesn't do its own class-loading,
and I've customized it to write time-per-test information to stdout, etc...
Eventually I will add the no-asserts warning to my versions of CppUnit and
JUnit.
Does the current JUnit have a tree view of test-cases within test-suites
within other test-suites? If it did, then the lowest-level view of a single
test-case could display the assert count, or perhaps turn some color if
there were no asserts.
Did the code that someone wrote to look for TestCase subclasses in specified
directory hierarchies or jar files, and automatically run them, get put into
JUnit or made public?
